>— First series —

>They went to some adventures like anime version. And finally Louie was get an ancient magic ring from dungeon and gave it to Aila. (Merrill and Aila were heroine for Louie in the novel version. And he chose Aila as his lover in the last volume of First series.)
But, that ancient magic ring had been cursed. The ring has confined Aila to itself. Then they become to be seeking the means to rescue Aila while adventures to various place of the Alecrast continent.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>192882210
–- Second series —
Occur to crisis of war between Ohfun kingdom and Fundria-Romar alliance. Mastermind is ルキアル(Rukiaru – Sorry, I don’t know Alphabet spelling for his name.), he is a clever tactician of Romar. Also, he would be main opponent of Louie in 2nd and 3rd series, and another hero of Louie novels.
King Rijarl was acknowledged Louie as his son, then dispatched Louie to Ohfun’s allies countries as secret envoy for prepare for the crisis of war. Finally, Louie will break through various conspiracies and achieved its purpose. In addition, Louie found a magic item that can rescue to Aila! Aila had returned from cursed magic ring, so Louie and his party’s purpose had also been achieved by that thing.
But Rukiaru’s ambition is very huge, and finally he revived the great ancient spirit which can ruin the world. It is an invincible ancient spirit except attacking from ancient legendary magic swords called “VanBlade”. Then Louie will go in search of VanBlade to central and east side of the Alecrast continent.
–- Second series —
–- Third series —
Louie will go in search of VanBlade to central and east side of the Alecrast continent. Oran: the Country of the Magi, Lodoss: the Cursed island and etc… Meanwhile, Rukiaru brings the democratic revolution to the continent that was ruled to monarchy with used a variety tactics. This act is not from good faith. It creates a great deal of confusion and will stripped the power of people to counteract for the ancient spirit.
Finally, Louie will get genuine VanBlade. Then he head to the final battle together with his party(Melissa, Genie, Merrill, and Parn with Deedlit from Lodoss island.) and great many Adventurer who were gathered by Aila. The final battle begins. To ancient spirit with revolutionary army that has been instigated by Rukiaru.

name: Anonymous
text:
Why is every admiral except for Akainu so damn useless?
>Aokiji
>Lazy and unmotivated, lets himself being hit by clearly inferior fighters because it's to tiring having to move away. Never finishes the fucking job
>Kizaru
>Overpowered devil fruit, can shoot lazers/or become one and yet failed to capture the rookies at Sabaondy, every single one of them escaped. Has no strong will or desire, even lazier than Aokiji
>Garp(yeah, vice admiral that refused multiple times to become an admiral)
>Biggest Marine Legend, fought on equal terms with the Pirate King
>Doesn't try to fight Whitebeard
>Doesn't try to save his grandson only to regret it later
>Did nothing in the war but punch Marco in his mug
>Sengoku
>Another legendary Marine
>Let's Luffy get away with Mr. Three and Ace
>Has enough power to treat Blackbeard like a bitch even after eating Whitebeard's fruit, and yet did nothing to make sure Ace got killed
Now we get my guy
>Akainu
>Relentless and tenacious, this fucker won't let you go. Win or lose, you're going to experience hell
>Fried Whitebeard's organs, took half of his face and brain, which basically sentenced his dead even if he managed to escape
>Takes two massive island destroying hits at point blank, still manages to get up and punch a whole in Jimbei's chest and cook Luffy's in the process
>Fights all the commanders by himself because he's fucking crazy and hates pirates more than anyone
>Only stops because Sengoku was his chief in command
>Makes Blackbeard and his whole gang run like little bitches when it's just him on a navy ship with a bunch of fodders

Fujitora seems a complex character so I won't say anything bad from him just yet, but he hasn't produced results either.

>>192879221
There was a single sequence in OPM when I felt actual terror. Naturally, that couldn't come from the heros' side cuz, aside from the fact no one actually dies in this manga, we are accustomed to expecting the heros to survive/be somehow saved, so even when someone actually dies, we don't feel the terror of their death being inevitable beforehand. Most monsters in OPM die either too quick thus not giving us the time to care or feel it, or are able to spar for a while thus not granting the feelings of one-sided feeling of despair to arise and fester. That is usually the case with other media too.

But this one's different. The octupus monster felt the terror and hopelessness of it's situation, and so did I. This moment genuinely shocked me as I never experienced anything alike. A slow, agonizing and certain death for something that seemed so mighty at first. It doesn't even see what's exactly happening, but it knows it's fucked as he desperately tries to cling to life with all it's might. I didn't just felt bad for it. I was it.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>15510851
News on development and partnerships aren't going to affect the price much at this point, it seems. We need people using the network which will come with time. I also think the ethereum network might be a contributing factor to lack of activity since it's slow and can be expensive.

With all of these other blockchains using or saying they'll use chainlink for their smart contracts, developers might just be waiting for a better platform to arise.

You also have to remember that we are still very early and people are probably still trying to figure out how they can utilize the chainlink network or even smart contracts in general. I work for an iot company and in order to make anything useful, we need the ability to securely allow user credentials (api keys) to be used for basically every api call. That might be solved with TEEs or this new mixicles idea, but that's yet to be seen.

I think once we see what the 50 oracle startups are working on, we'll be a better idea of where we're headed.

pros:
directly owning real estate gives massive leverage and relatively large returns before expenses
you can more easily collateralize your existing real estate to buy more real estate
cons:
illiquid. Stop losses don‘t exist
Niggertenants. It‘s not a meme. You cant legally deny them housing either.
property taxes suck
your tenants will destroy the house - you have to know how to do all the repairs yourself to save on labor costs.
if your house of cards comes falling down you pretty much lose your entire portfolio forever. No bank will lend to you ever again.
single white males in their late 20s/early 30s will smoke so much weed the inside paint of the house will crack and discolour. They will also NEVER clean the bathroom.
Your tenants will skip out on last month‘s rent and ding dong ditch the house. You‘ll never recover it
A lawyer and an accountant are absolutely necessary.

If you can get through all the bullshit though, you should have higher returns to match your efforts. Most people don‘t get through the bullshit though.

>>15511017
Short selling has been around a lot longer than any of us have. And as much as I despise most of them, I still have to recognize that they serve an important part in the economy.

In order for there to be a buyer, there must be a seller. For all of those who think the value of a stock or metal is going to go up, there has to be the counter-party who think it's going to go down. If you didn't have both, there would be no trade.

But even the short sellers in silver don't have all the power. The big problem they face is that silver has utility and will never go to zero. While there is certainly reason to short SOME of the miners, shorting the metal itself (depending on the price) isn't a smart idea.

>Aggregation: Some mechanism exists for turning private judgements into a collective decision.

A currency war with china that forces Crypto into mainstream adoption from all sides due to inflationary pressures and currency manipulation, and chainlink hopefully and supposedly will be the onramp for this mass exodus into the new financial markets of electronic money, money with "no lag and lash" as you keenly noticed.

I do wonder however how energy will fare. The energy cost of energy continues to grow, meaning less profit systematically no matter how efficiently the energy is used, which is interesting considering how much the system currently relies on proof of work energy sucking computational power. I cant claim to see the solution to that one.

Please not I am not a link namefag, I simply think link will be important to this board in the future and I believe this board will be pivotal when crypto truly takes off. Also as such I will not use a tripcode, so to sate my own autistic features I will say now my name means strength of god, and if there is ever a dispute as to the legitamency of who is speaking i will refer to this.

yellow is magnetic field

space/time flowers as a geometry in this 3-6-9 ratio sequence

>3: 3 colours (magnetic - yellow, electric - blue, time - green)
>6: magnetic (sin) + electric (cos) + time (unit circle) oscillating in 2D (3x2 = 6)
>9: summation of these 3 colours to create the time helix (2D projection + 3 colours = 9)
>look into the tesseract scene in the movie Interstellar to get a better visual, the gif I posted is only a 3D representation of a 4D phenomena

If you want to get more mathematical you should look into how euler's number 'i' is used to map from the time domain to the frequency domain

it simplifies electrical formulas form PDEs (partial differential equations as functions of time) into phasors (vectors) and transforms the equations into simple arithmetic and algebra instead of solving complicated calculus
it's an amazing insight

>They murdered Aaron Swartz

Death
On the evening of January 11, 2013, Swartz was found dead in his Brooklyn apartment by his partner,[101] Taren Stinebrickner-Kauffman.[68][102][103] A spokeswoman for New York's Medical Examiner reported that he had hanged himself.[102][103][104][105] No suicide note was found.[106] Swartz's family and his partner created a memorial website on which they issued a statement, saying: "He used his prodigious skills as a programmer and technologist not to enrich himself but to make the Internet and the world a fairer, better place."[19]

Days before Swartz's funeral, Lawrence Lessig eulogized his friend and sometime-client in an essay, Prosecutor as Bully. He decried the disproportionality of Swartz's prosecution and said, "The question this government needs to answer is why it was so necessary that Aaron Swartz be labeled a 'felon'. For in the 18 months of negotiations, that was what he was not willing to accept."[107] Cory Doctorow wrote, "Aaron had an unbeatable combination of political insight, technical skill, and intelligence about people and issues. I think he could have revolutionized American (and worldwide) politics. His legacy may still yet do so."[108]

Your pic related is talking about something very similar to Spiral Dynamics. Look it up if you are interested further in this type of analysis of human/mass consciousness. I would say that in spiral dynamics terms, the level 1 in the pic is starting from blue(traditional) and going into orange(modern) level. Level 2 starts from orange and moves to green(post modern/collective). 3rd level is yellow(integral), which is a higher tier as it sees everything as perspectives, systems, shades of grey, and overcomes the more retarded parts of the collectivism of the green level. There are higher and lower levels than these, but it makes sense that the anon in that pic would only see these 3 levels, as the lower(or higher) levels do not really exist in developed western countries in any significant manner.

replies.text:
>>72619199
Just start ASAP -- don't spend too much time trying to learn everything before you begin. Just jump in and start writing. You'll have time to continue learning while you're working but the best way to learn is to just do and split test. See what works, what doesn't, etc.

From there it's really just a numbers game until you've built up a decent client list and portfolio. Once you've carved out your own little corner in whatever niche you're wanting to sell in, you start having clients come to you and you won't have to do much outreach.

But when you're first starting off, expect to send a shit ton of emails, pitches, proposals, and even some spec work if you're feelin ballsy.

One of my earliest pitches to a company was an email saying "your landing page is pretty terrible, I re-wrote it and included a mockup attached below, have your web team run an A/B test with it against your current LP and shoot me an email back in 3 weeks when you see how much better your conversions are."

Oh, and find a niche you prefer to write in. I personally stay away from cosmetics and anything dealing with medicinal claims, FDA regulations, etc. but there is a ton of money there for those who specialize in it.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72625244
It's not terrible, and could be a lot worse (like Windows support, or having to be a phone representative). I mostly work with RHEL in the office (remotely diagnosing and resolving issues via CLI tools), and a modified version of Fedora when I occasionally have to go and diagnose an issue for a client offsite. It's a downgrade from my previous role as a sysadmin, but I guess I moved to the wrong town at the wrong time, 'cause I couldn't find any open sysadmin positions for the past couple of months, and eventually had to take this. The free breakfast and beer make it tolerable, as do the friendly coworkers. I'm still making half as much as I used to, but I have enough in savings to justify staying on for a bit, at-least the contract period. Hopefully I'll buddy up to the sysadmin here, and he'll leave or die or something, then I'll take his place, or they'll move me up to a managerial role in the department. Otherwise I'm out in 9 months.

>>72599790
>I can't understand how anyone gets infected via the web, unless web browser devs install intentional back doors.
Many programmes are networked, in particular web connected, such as PFD viewers (really bad security track record) , time sync programs (ntp had a bad bug a while ago), installation software and more. Just monitor your firewall and see the massive traffic that runs continuously. And one slip-up in these programmes will open the flood gates for malware.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72619513
Definitely unique_ptr, you're looking at zero cost, not just zero overhead. At reallocation, just 'move' a new array.
Make your own templated class and remember what a vector<T> needs:
contiguous series of Ts
O(1) get_at(idx), O(N) find(value), O(1) amortised insert(value), O(N) remove(idx).
Always allocate more than you use. I recommend logarithmic growth (find a steep log value so you don't destroy your heap). Keep m_alloc_cnt and m_used_cnt.
If you really want to show off to the teacher for bonus points, specialise basic types (char, int, ...) to use 10-30 elements in the stack instead of slowly allocating to heap. I mean literally
T m_stack_arr[64 / sizeof(T)];
So you fit a single cache line. Or something similar, show off buzzwords. Then just need a boolean flag whether you're still in stack or gone to the heap. Again you can optimise that info in a bit field somewhere.
This will definitely win bonus points.
Good luck.

Even for statically sized arrays, if you want to prevent UB you have to validate at runtime. This incorrect code compiles, even though it invokes UB. 
int a = 10;
int array[10] = {0};
return array[a];

so either you allow UB or you validate at runtime.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72613134
The tips that fit me and seal are ER38-15SML, the long stem smalls. But only after hours of breaking in. It's an odd material that expands and softens with use. I tried pressure steaming a pair and they shrunk. Regular smalls are too short for me, and mediums are too wide. You can check whether they're sealed by doing a sort of burp, and you'll feel resistance on your eardrums if they are. It's neat to watch on an endoscope. Inverting the large flange between uses restores the shape. There's also foam tips which many prefer.

I'll assume you can figure out how to clip the cable to your shirt. I keep seeing people use IEMs with the cables under tension and then complain about them transferring vibration.

replies.text:
>>72611527
The tuning is made possible by the enclosure and porous driver mounting. Planar headphones tend to lack the acoustical elements that result in a bass boost.

As for what is different about the Fostex bio-cellulose (cellulose Iα) drivers:
It's a lightweight and stiff material, and with more internal losses than typical hard metals. I was under the impression that Fostex/Foster prefers a composite diaphragm sandwich of bacterial cellulose between aramid layers to better balance rigidity.
I'm not sure how this comes into play with the Foster designs in a headphone. It does have a separate surround, which is rare among headphones and required by the material choice. Most headphones integrate the surround directly in the central radiating area, but the stiff cone has to have it separate, as typical of loudspeaker drivers.
Without a specific sample to do a complete teardown, the linearity of the suspension is not known to me. It would avoid the pitfall of the radiating area being significantly modulated with the excursion, regardless of particulars.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72624927
>>72624909
>Still not sure what the exact acoustic definition of this word is.
>Me neither, and there's no way to measure it I think
Separation is the subjective perception of sound sources as they fit into the human brain's model of localization. We can talk about modeling the physical stimuli that lead to subjective response, but these are fundamentally different things.
When you have a time signal, you can look at its amplitude and how that amplitude changes with time. The brain has two signals fed into it, one from each ear. This also means that you can look into how the two signals are different from each other. These compose the measurable information. Building a virtual model of hearing is not equivalent.
>Also I learned that after applying an EQ the phase gets changed
This is generally true of EQ, at least the normal minimum-phase variant.
>so you should also correct for that with an FIR.
No.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72609851
An older M -- assuming it isn't a late blue badge (1996 and later) -- will provide you with:
1. Better build quality, especially insofar as the case is concerned
2. Better sound
3. Better looks
But it also comes with the downsides of:
1. Very likely having broken rivets (too many of these and you will need to bolt mod)
2. No modern keys like Windows keys
3. Can be difficult finding in a decent-ish condition, will almost always require cleaning and so on

Unicomp might have the short stick insofar as some of the build quality and looks are concerned, but for the most part you're getting what people like about M's the most; which is the buckling springs. Their QA has issues, though, so there's a chance they send you out a shite unit. I still recommend Unicomp overall if you want to try out buckling springs.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72616649
Have a Dactyl Manuform built for you. You've got the money to get it with SLA printing, Zeal switches, Amoeba pcbs with MillMax hotswap, and all that good shit. If you don't want to have something made for you, go Kinesis.

Drop the fullsize ANSI bullshit. That layout is a clone of a lever actuated typewriter layout, with all the results of limitations from the lever actuation still present. Keys moved off center horizontally to let the levers sit side by side, keys stuck on one block for more direct lever->paper linkage, keys at the same height despite different finger lengths since the horizontal stagger prevents it, lack of thumb usage since the linkage would be impossible, etc. Get something designed to fit human hands instead of something to copy obsolete, and highly flawed, technology.

>>72617924

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72617945
Then get into them. You WILL develop uncurable chronic pain later in life without them. Most people make the mistake of only getting into them to mitigate RSI and prevent flare ups, but it's too late to not have RSI by then.

There is not one single human with two fully functioning hands who should not be using a split ergo board with columnular stagger by choice. It's a straight up better layout for human hands.

First off don't get cherry brown, you don't feel ANY tactility at all when typing. You can only feel it very slightly if you slowly press down the switch.
You can get a Durgod RGB keyboard for around 130$
You can get an iKBC TD108 for almost half the price but with better keycaps & build quality. It's full sized though
Your best option would be to get a cheaper mech and then replace the keycaps. Brands like Durgod, iKBC, Ducky all make overpriced junk. You can get something like the Plugable Performance or a Tecware Phantom. Tecware Phantom is basically an RGB version of the Plugable with usb passthrough but very slightly thinner keycaps.
Outemu switches are the same as Cherry but with smoother linears and slightly more tactile browns/blues (at the expense of being louder)

subject: /pcbg/ - PC Building General
name: Boycott Week 3
text:
ATTENTION: Graphics card prices are excessive by historical standards; therefore, consumers should delay or completely forgo any midrange to high end graphics card purchases. The gouging has two root causes: lack of market competition and shortage/"new normal" pricing during the mining hayday.

>Assemble a part list
https://pcpartpicker.com/
>Example gaming builds and monitor suggestions; click on titles above parts lists to see notes
https://pcpartpicker.com/user/pcbg/saved/
>How to non-technically assemble a PC
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=69WFt6_dF8g

Want help?
>State budget & CURRENCY
>Post at least some attempt at a parts list
>List your uses, e.g. Gaming, Video Editing, VM Work
>For monitors, include purpose (e.g., photoediting, gaming) and graphics card pairing (if applicable)

CPUs based on current pricing:
>Athlon 200GE - HTPC, web browsing, bare minimum gaming (can be OC'd on most mobos with the right BIOS)
>R3 2200G - Recommended minimum gaming
>R5 2600/X - Good gaming CPU with great value
>R5 3600 - Great gaming CPU
>R7 2700 - Budget video editing
>R9 3900X - Professional tasks

RAM:
>Always choose at least a two stick kit; 2x 8GB is recommended
>CPUs benefit from high speed RAM; 3200CL16 is ideal
>AMD B and X chipsets and Intel Z chipsets support XMP

Graphics cards based on current pricing:
>AAA or multiplatform games: Radeon card appropriate for your montior
>PC centric games, VR games, or ray tracing: Nvidia card appropriate for your display
>Used RX 570s can be had for a steal; inquire about warranty
1080p 16:9
>RX 570 8GB - good performance with great value
>GTX 1660 - standard

General:
>PLAN YOUR BUILD AROUND YOUR MONITOR IF GAMING
>Don't bother buying a new monitor for gaming unless it's high refresh with adaptive sync
>A 250GB or larger SSD is almost mandatory; consider m.2 form factor
>Bottleneck checkers are worthless

Previous: >>72622649

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72627203
Aside from minor fan placement optimization.
I would say the case is fine and the cooler is fine.
But then we get to this
>Using IC-Diamond Thermal paste applied via rice grain method, no spreading manually.
Ic diamond is one of the harder to use thermal pastes out on the market. Mainly because it's extremely thick and unlike a lot of other pastes is neither easy to spread when mounting, nor does it spread and pumpout with thermal cycling as easily as other pastes.

Though it supposedly has excellent stability, more so in aggressive thermal cycling.
I would say you should definetly check your thermal paste application with this paste.
You should also thermal cycle it as it can easily take 24 hours to a week to make it spread out and create a better contact patch.

But yeah high likely hood that your paste application is imperfect and the paste needs time to "cure" by thermal cycling which makes it easier to spread and the pumpout effect helps remove excess.

If you are going to take it apart to check application, absolutely take pictures.

I also suggest you use X method.

Lastly, careful about removing the IC diamond paste, as it can stratch the surface if you use anything hard while pressing on it. So a soft cloth should be fine, but the applicator tip, small plastic anything like that will leave scratch marks easily.

I got more info, so ask if you want to know something.

Assuming top/rear is exhaust and front is intake wit ha DRP 4 your temperatures seem a bit too high. I would advise applying the thermal paste again with a spread method, you mentioned in a different post you used rice grain which is fine for the most part, but spreading is a more consistent method. Remember that too little thermal paste can be a problem, while too much is not for thermals. I would also do a check to make sure everything is tight and that you do not have a lack of clamping from the cooler to the CPU and motherboard.

>>72621227
In the same boat as >>72621231, but I've taken the optimizer pill. Built an IR and implemented some basic optimizations on top of it before register coloring to assembly.
An optimizer is essentially a ton of math and a ton of graph theory. I find it more exciting to implement some optimizations rather than tweak an existing language a little bit and drop it after a year at most (after barely getting through semantic analysis).
As an additional upside, I basically only have to rewrite the front-end for any new language I decide to make in the future since the I have an IR.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72621783
First off, I assume your java invocation actually would be
java helloworld.HelloWorld

as the directory structure implies a class called HelloWorld inside the helloworld package.
The first one only differs by the fact that you're specifying a different directory for the Java runtime to look for user classes (i.e. those that do not ship as part of the Java runtime itself). By default it only searches the current directory (.), but you can also specify a number of directories or JAR files to search for classes instead.
That means Java will look for your main class in classes/helloworld/HelloWorld.class in the first case and helloworld/HelloWorld.class in the latter.
This concept is called the classpath.
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/tools/findingclasses.html

I was multithreading a parser with Open MP because it was too slow. After I finished the code it was still super slow, I checked it in the debugger and it really had spawned all the threads that it should but it seemed to still go sequentially, threads were just waiting.

Then I started it in the profiler and not the debugger and I had a speedup of more than 1000x. Keep in mind while I was using the debugger I still ran it in release mode. Without the debugger even the single threaded version is now faster than it needs to be. I wonder why that is, never seen such a difference between running in the VS debugger vs. just starting the .exe.
I think it might be because I use exceptions in many places? I don't know.

Lost over an hour on that, but now I am starting my weekend with a glass of wine.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72625554
That's because starting with 2 and in totality with 3, python decided to abandon the dream of replacing bash.

I actually agree for very very simple tasks, bash is better. The use case of bash scripts for me has been for tasks I would otherwise type in a single line on the terminal with copious use of "&&".

For complex operations, python is better than bash. Calling external programs from python isn't as easy as bash, but if you're doing anything with control and data structures inside of your script, you're probably a lot better off with python.

It's important to note that a lot of the usecase of bash is calling the GNU core utils, and the Python stdlib has many similar functions defined inside of it. os.walk() uses the same syscall as ls, but it's a lot easier to programmatically work with the data.

That's my own piece. I think you should learn DOS/Batch + Bash + Powershell eventually, but python should definitely be your priority.

replies.text:
>What are you working on, /g/?
Got my fizzbuzz down to 173 bytes

nasm -o fizz_buzz fizz_buzz.s

%define         stdout          1
%define         sys_write       4
%define         sys_exit        1
BITS 32
org     0x00200000
ehdr:
        db              0x7F,'ELF',1,1,1,0
        times 8 db      0
        dw              2
        dw              3
        dd              1
        dd              _start
        dd              phdr - $$ 
phdr:   dd              1
        dd              0
        dd              $$
        dw              1
        dw              0
        dd              filesize
        dd              filesize
        dd              5
        dd              0x1000
  
_start:
        push 0x0a0a0a0a
_loop:
        inc esi
        xor edi, edi
        _buzz:
        mov eax, esi
        mov bl, 5
        xor edx, edx
        div ebx
        test edx, edx
        jnz _fizz
        push 'Buzz'
        add edi, 4
        _fizz:
        mov eax, esi
        mov bl, 3
        xor edx, edx
        div ebx
        test edx, edx
        jnz _print_num
        push 'Fizz'
        add edi, 4
        _print_num:
        test edi, edi
        jnz _loop_print
                mov eax, esi
                _formatted_print:
                dec esp
                mov bl, 10
                xor edx, edx
                div ebx
                add dl, '0'
                mov byte [esp], dl
                inc edi
                test eax, eax
                jz _loop_print
                dec esp
                add al, '0'
                mov byte [esp], al
                inc edi
        _loop_print:
        mov al, sys_write
        mov bl, stdout
        mov ecx, esp
        add esp, edi
        inc edi
        mov edx, edi
        int 0x80
        and esp, 0xfffffffc
        _loop_end:
        cmp esi, 0x64
        jl _loop
_end:
        add esp, 4
        mov al, sys_exit
        xor ebx, ebx
        int 0x80

filesize        equ     $ - $$

Laravel:
$query = $query->where(function ($query) use ($max_price)

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72626714
Compare the first item to all of the items after it (all but the first item)
Then compare the second item to all of the items after it (all but the first and second)
Etc etc
This not only solves the counting with itself issue, but prevents redundant counting too

replies.name: Anonymous

>>72626724
Pointers are a really simple concept, and I think that most people actually do understand them.
What they fail to understand is the amount of book-keeping that (raw) pointers require you to have, in order to avoid derefencing a dangling pointer, memory leaks, things like that.
Pointers are simple, but understanding how to use them correctly is difficult.

When I first learned C/++, the hardest thing I couldn't understand is why people had so much trouble with pointers. It wasn't until learning about more advanced and more abstract concepts that I understood how pointers cause problems.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72626764
When using pointers, keeping track of their state is paramount, and this is often difficult to do. In many situations, pointers are being used in such a way that they will eventually lead to faults or leaks, or may be suboptimal and lead to unnecessary indirection, resulting in cache churn.
In these situations, the program will execute properly, but it is not "formally verified" and will likely not meet ideal performance standards--never crashing, never leaking, with fast execution.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>72627208
Yeah. For example, if you have this at global scope:
const int x = 42:

That's no different to
constexpr int x = 42:

Because the initialiser is a constant expression. But if you have
int foo();
const int y = foo();

Then it remains non-constedpr.

This has implications for things like linkage which may not be immediately obvious. Which is why it's better to be explicit.

we use assembly but we have really sophisticated cross assemblers that make it much easier. We also have cycle accurate emulator and a really really powerful real-time debugger (actually that debugger was made by a guy from my group, he's a big brain programmer I'll tell you that). Since we can do everything on pc we only have to test it on real hardware once it's done or almost done... The last big demo I worked on (ngc 1277 100%) was done all on pc and I only tested on real hardware for the last few days before release.

To get the stuff on real hardware... there's couple of ways. I have to add that real big demos also use custom loaders so you program the disk drive itself too (c64 floppy has its own cpu and ram) and at the end of the day you have a floppy disk image that you want to transfer to a real floppy or use a floppy disk emulator that pretends to be a real floppy drive to the c64 and reads the images from sd card... you can also connect the real floppy drive to pc with a parallel cable but you need a machine with dos for real time timings on the cable (my second picture shows exactly that, laptop with dos transferring floppy image to a real Commodore disk drive)

Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
"1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars"

>>21318125
I've only had experience with more than. Don't know how it will be with Hastings but with more than you had a dashboard that showed your score and What not. Don't know if Hastings has a curfew cut off but more than has one after 10/11pm where your usage score goes down the shitter for driving your own car late at night. Also the black box will monitor how many miles you drive in the year and if you hit that limit it you can't drive your car anymore until you purchase additional miles or they cancel the insurance.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>21318125
Forgot to mention there is also a speed and "smoothness" score. Speed is self explanatory. Smoothness is basically how quickly you get up to speed and how quickly you slow down. In simple terms drive like a granny. Accelerate slowly and brake really early. It's horrible but give it a year or two and you can get a policy without a black box for about the same, sometimes cheaper. Best to check your insurance rates that are on offer every year to find ones that are either cheaper or don't need a black box.

replies.name: Waifusquad
replies.text:
>>21317893
Stickers here are usually printed on Oracal 3651 automotive grade PVC vinyl. They are printed using eco-solvent printers, which instead of sublimating on the surface of a paper like inkjet printers, actually dissolves into the vinyl. They are then typically cold laminated with UV protective laminate. That way they last up to 5 years outdoors generally, whereas inkjet prints will fade/dissolve when exposed to sunlight. You cannot inkjet print on PVC vinyl, it's nonporous and nonabsorbent.
A standard printing setup will cost you about $8,000-20,000 for the printer alone and will take 1000-3500W of power when at load. The solvents are a hazard and must be disposed of properly. If the printer is not operated almost consistently it will squirt out some of the solvent in order to keep the print heads clean. If you leave the printer off for a period of time it will clog and damage the print heads. If the print heads break, that's a few thousand dollars typically. The calibration on them is extensive; you typically need to re-calibrate the color, print settings, and cutting whenever you change a roll of vinyl. Printing your own vinyl this way is not substantially cheaper to the point where it would be economic for osg vendors to print for themselves. We outsource our printing to a handful of printers (There are less than ten I'd say that offer this service) and most of them offer sign printing for local businesses as well.

I give you a protip: The fact that the US auto industry developed in the Midwest has always influenced American car design to a large extent. The traditional American V8 barge was designed for comfortable cruising in the flat open spaces of the Midwest/Plains states. It needed to be big and comfy, but not necessarily good handling.

California was always a hotbed for imports because Japanese and European cars are better adapted to the road conditions of that state, which are closer to what you would find in Japan.

The W-body project started soon after the A-bodies hit showrooms in fall 1981. replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
GM used nine different four cylinder engines when Smith's tenure as CEO began. Five of these were used in European cars and one was an Isuzu engine. Two were manufactured domestically (Iron Duke and the Cavalier "junkyard" engine).

During Smith's tenure, they got rid of three of those engines while adding several more (Quad 4, Saab H, and Saturn engines). Most of them were redundant and totally unnecessary.

He couldn't resolve this clusterfuck, especially for an MBA who had been a GM lifer and with the company since graduating college.

>>21321900
I give the guy credit because he was the first person in a position of power at GM in many moons who gave any consideration to building cars other than rental fleet shitboxes, but those halo projects didn't do anything to fix the systematic problems accumulated over the last two decades.

When Lutz was at BMW, Ford of Europe, and Chrysler, he had a good sense for product that would sell. By the time he was at GM, he'd become too out-of-touch with the real world and only wanted to build cars for himself.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: As I see it, if Lutz were really the heroic gonzo car guy people think he was, GM's depressing bean counter culture would have quickly robbed him of his life force and he would have quit or been fired in short order, but the fact that they kept him until the bailout was proof that he was the go-to guy for GM’s “business as usual” action plan.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>21321918
The history of the American automobile is littered with money-losing halo projects like the Continental Mark II, Avanti, and Buick Reatta. These cars make classic car shows fun to attend, but they merely cost their respective companies a fuckton of money. The Solstice and GTO may someday be admired at classic car shows, but did nothing to right the listing ship of GM.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>21321957
>>21321918
Halo projects are a fun-time excursion a company does when things are booming and sales are good. The Plymouth Prowler was such a car--a fun project Chrysler and Lutz undertook in the mid to late 90s when the US economy was soaring and anything with four wheels would sell.

Problem was, GM in the 2000s was a sinking ship and that was not the time for low volume novelty cars. The first thing you do in a downturn is trim out non-essentials. Why do you suppose Japanese companies ditched their sports cars during the late 90s Asian recession? Toyota couldn't live on Supras.

Go /p/ro:
• Please post images that are JPG format, smaller than 1 MB, and/or about 1000 pixels on the longest side.
• Expect to be judged harshly. Learn to deal with it.

Want:
• We come here for photos, so post yours as often as possible, even if "image unrelated" to your text.
• "Flickr/500px/Tumblr/Facebook/Portfolio" threads are for critique and networking
• Use "Recent Photos" threads if you are shy or only want to post a couple of photos.
• Shared raw files which we can collectively edit for discussion of post-processing techniques, are encouraged.
• Use the catalog to consolidate similar topics (photographic themes, images or technical gear threads)

Do Not Want:
• Go to >>>/r/ for specific Photoshop requests.
• Gear threads are discouraged, but identified as necessary. Many users simply hide these threads.

straight horizons

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: Portrait and product photography so you can use a high f-stop and low ISO and then you’ll invariably need a slow shutter speed.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3530477
Exposure stacking, focus stacking, panoramas. I.e. any method using multiple photos in post-production.
Photographing with telephoto lenses.
Panning.
Waiting long for a subject to appear, e.g. in nature photography, or taking photos in fixed area using heavy gear, e.g. sports.
Photos of yourself taken with remote control.
Holding equipment other than camera, e.g. in studio.

When making a still life, having the camera fixed at a stationary point is useful for creating perspective, as it allows you to make fine adjustments to the items within the frame while being confident that you still have the same exact angle for your framing.

And, because its also technically related to photography, stop motion animation benefits greatly from a tripod.

replies.text:

>Are they worth the money?
No, you'd be better off buying a 70-300mm kit lens and cropping out an area to give you the same FoV. it would have better quality. thats how shitty those lenses are.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3530864
Have one, regret buying it.
Mine is a 800mm F/8, I get better results with my east german Pentacon 135mm f/2.8 and cropping the shit out of it.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3530923
I tested both lenses at a highway sign standing about 1,5 km away and got better results with my Pentacon at f/2.8 than with the 800 mm mirror lense.
To make sure it wasn't due to the slow lense and high shutter speed I cranked the ISO up untill I maxed out my fastest shutter speed of 1/4000 second and still got shitty results.

replies.name: Sugar
replies.text:
>>3531855

this is not true because if it were then I could handhold large format cameras in dark rooms at 1/500 sec at f/64 and get a shot

media size has nothing to do with the ability to gather light, look at cell phone cameras. it has everything to do with how close the photosites, those are the individual sensors on the actual wafer inside the camera, it has to do with how close they are to each other

say my Df has 16mp right, FF sensor. i've lot a lot more real estate to put those 16mp on. each individual photosite is a set distance apart from the next one, on the wafer. Now if I want to go to like, 1600 or 3200 ISO, those photosites push up their signal to noise ratio to make them more sensitive to light. Because they are microscopically spread so far apart, the noise generated from each one doesn't bleed over into the neighboring photosites as easy.

However on a 24mp crop sensor like on your 80d, those photosites are a lot closer to each other and at higher ISOs that noise generated at each photosite tends to bleed over into neighboring photosites moreso than it does on the 16mp Df or any 16mp FF sensor really.

Your 80d is still going to BTFO most compacts and cell phone cameras at high ISOs with comparative lenses, cell phones get their ability to gather light from software processing and fast prime lenses, not the ability of the sensor to gather light. Try to find some faster f1.8 or f1.4 lenses, an older camera with a fast lens is always going to shit on a newer camera with f2.8 zoom glass. If you don't believe me, this was taken on a 2005 Canon 5D with a 50 1.8 handheld and at 1600 ISO

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3531848
>how is this possible? I can't even get to 6400 without getting a shit ton of nose
He's shooting JPEG with NR or he used NR when processing his RAW. A73's are not "crystal clear" at ISO 32,000. But with a little processing they can make good small/medium prints at that ISO.

You should be able to do the same at ISO 6400 with a newer crop camera.

>>3531850
Pixel density has nothing to do with it so long as gapless microlenses are involved. It's just the difference in format / sensor size / light gathering.

>>3531863
Don't shoot at fractional ISOs. They can have the noise of the next higher whole ISO without the same exposure. (Where this happens depends on sensor.) This should have been shot at ISO 3200 then pulled down if you wanted a dark/moody image.

Aside from that the noise isn't all that bad, especially considering it's a low key / dark / underexposed image. Apply some NR and view it at the size you intend to print.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3531870
>media size has nothing to do with the ability to gather light,
LOL it's the #1 determining factor.

>look at cell phone cameras.
They're shit at high ISO without multi-frame AI blending and processing. You can do the same by taking 3-4 exposures in rapid succession, blending them in post, then cranking up the NR on the final image.

>it has everything to do with how close the photosites, those are the individual sensors on the actual wafer inside the camera, it has to do with how close they are to each other
Not since gapless microlenses, no.

>Because they are microscopically spread so far apart, the noise generated from each one doesn't bleed over into the neighboring photosites as easy.
What you're describing is basically blooming. But blooming had nothing to do with high ISOs and it hasn't been an issue for years. Photon shot noise dominates high ISO images. Read noise of any kind is almost irrelevant at ISOs like 6400.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3531379
Don't buy into the entry-level meme, especially when it comes to canon and nikon.

The biggest issue with nikon entry-level is that they take away the compatibility with older manual lenses, which should be standard. They took away the in body screwdrive autofocus motor, so u can't autofocus with older lenses that have the screwdrive feature, and you can't use older lenses on any cpu mode. Means you have to go full manual.

Its not the end of the world, but its essentially forcing you to either buy more expensive modern lenses or stick with affordable vintage lenses but git gud with manual. And also at the same price (maybe even cheaper) point of the entry level camera, you could get an older higher performance camera which probably works just as good if not better.

So i'd recommend finding a used d7100.

But also Nikon isn't very compatible with other lens ecosystems because of the way its lenses are mounted, so you'll be stuck with nikon lenses. A lot of other cameras, mirrorless especially work really well in adapting to other lens mounts using adapters.

subject: Tips on getting into Photojournalism
name: Anonymous
text:
I don't give a fuck about politics, but I find the pics taken in photojournalism more entertaining and i also think they're more engaging to others. I live in Toronto and a lot of protests happens here i guess.

-How do I know where shit is happening so I can go there and take pics?
-How would I position myself to take pics? Do I have to differentiate myself from the crowds somehow, or move with them? Can I just freely take pics of them protesting or whatever, are they gonna understand that im trying to document the story?
-Whats the best way of getting attention to the pics that I would take at these events? I don't care about making money, just would want them to get exposure, but I still wouldn't mind selling my pics of spidey to the daily bugle.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3525735
>Tips on getting into Photojournalism
Time travel back to WWII. Photojournalism is dead

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3525735
>How do I know where shit is happening so I can go there and take pics?
Check news outlets for calendar information; get to know the political groups, follow their social media and get on their communications lists; and keep your ear to the ground.

>How would I position myself to take pics?
You position yourself however you need to, but listen to law enforcement's commands and don't break the law. Know your rights as a photographer.

>Do I have to differentiate myself from the crowds somehow
No. Your camera differentiates you.

>Can I just freely take pics of them protesting or whatever
In the U.S., no one has a right to privacy if they're in the public. Check state laws, and know your rights.

>are they gonna understand that im trying to document the story?
You can't predict this. Just know your rights as a photographer.

>Whats the best way of getting attention to the pics that I would take at these events?
Contact a newsroom or journalist you know and offer your work. If they had their own photog at the event, they likely won't take your photos unless they're remarkable or you captured an amazing moment.

>I don't care about making money, just would want them to get exposure
Never work in trade for exposure. If you can't find a buyer, post your pics on Instagram or Twitter with a use disclaimer. It's also a good idea to contact your local news outlet for stringer opportunities.

t.journalist

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3525735

The fact you have to ask this means you're not ready to 'get into photojournalism'. You don't apply for a job or something stupid like that, you just go and do it.

I have worked in Ukraine doing conflict journalism since 2014. I got involved by quitting my shitty office job and just going there with a camera and interest in the situation. Learned Russian and Ukrainian, and I get published sometimes. It's not rocket science.

That being said, it's also not as cool and exciting as you probably think it is. You will care about making money when you're spending hundreds - maybe thousands - on drivers to take you places, translators (which you will probably need unless you're going to learn a local language, and Google doesn't help), fixing costs, gear breaking, body armour, etc.

Good 'photojournalists' are adept at blending into a situation and living interesting lives. A camera is just a tool, not a key to interesting work. Go to events and make work. Interview people, write notes, make photo stories, write blogs, etc. Don't rely on social media.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
Here is an excellent example of photojournalism.

A photo taken at a job fair for autists.

A person with greasy skin and a fedora.

Now this captures autism better than anything else.

This example of photojournalism is so good it could be transformed into a meme.

The key to good photojournalism is having a camera and having an eye for what could be transformed into a meme.

Something that could be easily transformed into a 4chan meme is something that would make a good newsworthy photo, and is the key to photojournalism.

The only thing you need to do is get your camera and good lens and get out of your mommy’s basement.

name: Anonymous
text:
Why does everyone always say it's "fun" to shoot Fuji cameras?

What is it about Fuji that make it more fun than Canon/Nikon/Sony?

Is it just some sort of aesthetic feeling, or is there more to it?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
More dials because fuj autists believe shooting in manual only makes their snapshits more artistic

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529689
i-is it bad that I only use aperture priority?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
Mostly metal control dials on top of the camera like old film SLRs which are incredibly handy (for instance I always end up adjusting the shot with the compensation dial, which is mostly ignored by manufacturers) and super comfy jpeg settings/colors/custom simulations. Even if you work with raws only, they tend to be a valid reference point to start with. Also DR400@iso800 is great.

>>3529689
don't be salty anon, other brands are good too

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
Hipster autism.

Incompatibility with lightroom used to be a selling point for fujifilm.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: Because it feels like an instrument. They're solid and mechanical.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
>fun
I think this came from the x100.

A fixed focal length point and shoot camera but with metal construction, physical dials and "pro" like features. Also it looks cute so people wave at the camera.

I bought one and I hate "fun".

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529692
shutter priority is the thinking mans auto mode

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
I have an XT-2 it's a great camera idk if I would say it's any more "fun" than my D750. It's small well built and has physical dials. Take that however you want.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529689
I don't use the dials, I use the front and rear dials for everything. If you move the exposure compensation dial into C and the others into AUTO it unlocks command dials for manual exposure. A lot faster than using the dials.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529799
The top dials I mean that everyone memes about as if they're the only option to control the camera. Flexibility and customisability is a definite strength for Fuji. That's coming from someone who got bamboozled into buying an A6000 and hated it.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
/p/ enjoys questions that don't actually involve going to a store and demoing an actual camera

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
Try one out and see for yourself. It's pretty hard to describe and I guess what makes a camera "fun" is different for everyone.

If you want to basically LARP the film experience (manual exposure, physical dials, "film simulations", retro form factor/aesthetics) and go slow, you can.
If you want to use more automation, digital command dials to control your parameters etc. to go faster, you can.
If you want to switch between the two or do something in between, you can.
It's just a very well thought out camera concept that seems to be appealing to a lot of people. The retro dials immediately stand out, but what many people seem to forget is that underneath there's also an extremely solid, intuitive and configurable UI.

I also have experience with several Canon and Sony cameras, and while Fuji isn't "objectively" more "fun", it does have a very specific user experience. To me personally they're the most comfy to use, and also fun I guess, but I don't expect anyone else to share that opinion (dunno why a lot of folks here seem to get their jimmies rustled every single time this "fun" stuff is mentioned).

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
>Why does everyone always say it's "fun" to shoot Fuji cameras?
Marketing

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
I am a huge fujiboo and I love their cameras/lenses, but I don't think I can say it's any more "fun" to shoot them. I do like the build quality, ergo, and results these things can get you. I can definitely say people seem more relaxed if I have one of my Fujis compared to my Nikon FX gear.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529789
Why do you say that? You make controlling the DoF harder by using shutter priority instead of aperture. There are way less situations where shutter speed plays a role in a photo compared to aperture.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
I've recently gotten an X-T3 and I love it. I was waiting on Nikon's mirrorless offering but then they dropped those two Zturds so I gave up on them. I had been shooting mostly film on my Nikon FTN or on my Nikon F4s for quite a while. It's hard to describe, but the dials on the X-T3 are really sweet, "fun" is a good word. It feels more like a machine than a computer, I don't know if that makes sense.

The other main issue is Canon/Nikon/Sony all treat their crop sensor line as just the cheapo shit. Fuji is dedicated APSC so you can take advantage of smaller but good lenses. On an even more extreme example, I have a bunch of lenses for the Nikon 1 mirrorless system they just killed, and I liked that in some situations, for a similar reason: you can make really small glass for that sensor. It's not as extreme in the Fuji APSC world, but it's still a bit of an advantage there. For a concrete example, I've got a 30-110 lens for the Nikon 1, and that's equivalent to a 80-300 in a full frame. But it's the same size of my 50mm prime for the Nikon F, which is insane. There are advantages and disadvantages to a smaller sensor size, but smaller glass is probably the main advantage.

>>3530124
>>3530193
Pros = wedding photographers that's true, but there's lots of other situations where pros will always go manual. If you have more than a half-second to get the shot, you should be tweaking it in manual. So landscape, product photography, architecture/real estate, all should be manual. And even a lot of the stereotypical wedding photographers will dial in for the room and shoot manual that way.

Long term I think that Fuji's refusal to do full frame and just keeping it split on a dedicated APSC and a medium format will pay off. In 10 years time, how much of a gap between the two will still exist in-between where full-frame makes sense, and you wouldn't want either the smaller lighter APSC, or the bigger sensor?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3522959
>Stretched out the background, smaller subject makes the viewer less likely to pixel peep, also looks more realistic (you don't have the phone in front of your nose)
>Added a bit of noise to the phone display
>played with curves and color balance to eliminate the cyan shine on the fingers and adjusted it to the screen picture
>Played around with gamma levels on the display and overexposed the highlights a tiny bit, to make it more imperfect
>Added additional lightcone downwards with a plugin (like 10% soft light) and tried to recreate how the headlights fall on the skin
>eventually addded red shine on the right side of the hand to fake the impression the picture was taken there, logically it doesn't make sense, but it's just an additional color to integrate the hand into the picture

I'd say the most important things were the noise in the display and light adjustments on the hands. If you don't know how to do what I explained look into masking. I did this with Affinity, it's a very cheap program.

Something I noticed just now. Look at the relationship between display noise to hand noise in the picture. Realistically, the phone will always have a higher proportion of noise, regardless of which camera takes the picture. It's a pixelated display after all. So make sure to adjust the relationship between those two.

Really stupid question there :
I have got a 35mm film to devellop. I think some of my pic are bad and I dont want to print everyone of them.

If I order a digital version of my film, should I use this digital version for printing or should I use the film as a base for printing?

What 's your workflow when it comes to print your film?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3524497
Since you don't develop yourself I doubt you have the hardware to do analog prints, so I'd suggest getting scans and printing the ones you like.
As a bonus:
You can edit them before printing if you want.
If your printer has insufficient quality, you can still order prints from the (maybe edited) scans later.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3524529
Thanks. So there is no purpose develloping the film. I should just order the digital version and then print it right?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3524542
Most people shooting film do it like that, just that some devellop and scan the film themselfes, edit the pics on their computer and then print them.
In your case I don't known how good your printer is, but chances are it is good enough to produce good enough results on the right paper.
If not, order prints you want from the lab later.
Also analog prints aren't even usualy made by most labs anymore, especialy colour prints are nearly all digital nowerdays.

For the paper I better inform you that standard A4 paper used for copies etc. sucks for prints, they make special shiny photo-paper for that purpose wich yields much better results.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
How do you use a camera flash on an all manual camera?
Like, how do I know how much to compensate my exposure with the flash on?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3524566
Trial and error
It will greatly depend on how you're aiming the flash too, whether direct, with a small diffuser, big-ish diffuser, bouncing off walls, etc. I actually just keep my shutter and iso the same at 1/80, 100, and my aperture either wide open or down to 3ish for sharpness, and then really just modify the flash power. For up close with a diffuser taped to the flash pointing upwards I use 1/128-1/64, ~9-11 foot ceiling bounce a little farther away anywhere from 1/64-1/16 depending on how far, portrait focal lengths (like 10-15 feet away) with single/multiple wall bounce and the flash set up as slave closer to the subject anywhere from 1/32-1/4. I'm using a yongnuo yn560 IV, ymmv.

What I would do if I were to get a car photography gig:

1. Get a polarising filter to block out reflections on the windows/windscreen (if wanted). If the reflections look good, I'd keep them.

2. If shooting in a busy area with lots of people like >>3524829 mentioned, I'd either carry an ND filter and do a long exposure, or take multiple shots and them merge them in Photoshop (I'd prefer doing the latter).

replies.name: Anonymous

>>3527337
I'm unsure if it even gets tracked under shutter actuations to be honest.
But if it does it's only for opening the mechanical shutter, whatever the shutter speed you set during video is done with the electronic shutter.
Also while that site is a good source, the sample size is really small
And people are generally more likely to report a failure than "oh yeah it still works"

Regarding EOS M however, I don't really know for a fact, but EF-M isn't the best lens mount system you can buy into.
First off, it's relatively new and doesn't get too much love. This translates to a not all that well saturated used market. It'll probably get better with time but yeah, that's a thing to consider.

Since you're a beginner buyer in general, a really good thing to know is that glass matters much more than the body itself.
Buy a camera that lets you use the lenses you'd like to use because really, any reasonably modern camera body is going to perform well enough, especially for a beginner.

replies.text: I'm using Luminar 3 and when I do a mass export like 5% of photos are in a random different resolution. Specifically my camera is in RAW mode and the dimensions come out to 5134 x 3456. When I edit in luminar and export everything, most of my photos come out in that resolution, but a few random ones for some reason are 5202 x 3465. Does this make any sense?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3527974
>how crucial is the calibration target?
Depends on what you want. IT8 targets aren't magic or perfect but they're a requirement in most cases.

Scanners don't really see in color.
They don't know what pink is, and they sure as hell doesn't know what cyans or yellows are. What they do is capture up to 16 bits of grey in three separate channels. Combining these channels creates a color image but all colors are false. All of these "colors" get made up on the spot from a mixture of red, green, and blue values with no greater context so there's no accuracy in representation of original colors. They are precise, but inaccurate. Things can literally look like completely different colors in the scan compared to the original.

Calibration fixes 99% of this.
IT8 is the industry standard way of dealing with this.
Some methods are superior and some require using more than one physical target but they aren't standardized or widely available.

It's possible to do this manually with curves and shit but you'll go autistic and gain 400lbs and die long before you get even two colors nailed down and it only gets more complicated as you try and correct more colors without fucking up previous ones.

It's all a game of (what goes in) + (what comes out) + (knowing what went in) + (making adjustments) = making future scans more accurate by applying corrections made knowing what's wrong and what it should be closer to.
Working while ignoring this issue leads to wasted time trying to correct color or just bad images in the end.

Check out the mouse-over examples at this site
http://www.computer-darkroom.com/it8cal/it8_page_1.htm

>I'm looking into buying an 8200i for $250, but does not come with the target.
Is it used?
You can buy targets separately. They're usually well under $100 but there's not many places selling them. Be sure to buy only standard targets if you're not using Silverfast because not all software can use Silverfast's "advanced" targets or special ones

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3528190
Would those be the ones shot on wide angle lens? If that's the case you may be seeing the effects of lens corrections being done. Now I'm not using luminar, but when you do lens corrections, image can crop a little depending on the program used. On more modern cams that bake lens correction into raw you only see full captured resolution by using certain programs like rawtherapee. Lightroom for example, will only show what baked in raw will want you to see.

replies.text:
I have a few stupid ones.

With apertures, I thought bigger apertures meant things were more unfocused and had a limited focus distance but yet I see some that are f1.8 and have an entire building in focus. How?

What prime should I get for traveling? I'd mostly be taking portraits and images of cities and landmarks, maybe some landscapes. 35mm or 50mm?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529400
Tighter apertures essentially "crop" depth of field compared to wider apertures.
One thing you're not realizing is the closer you are to the camera the narrower the depth of field is. The further you are, the wider.

You can use a long lens with a tight aperture and your depth of field will be narrow but still wide enough to capture a building. That's how they do it. f1.8 is insane in Macro but still enough to capture most of a model's face in portraits. It more or less scales accordingly. The further you are, the wider fov is.

>>3530016
800 is for flight, for stationary it depends on birb species and what it's doing. You should be able to go down to 160 at times, even lower with good stabilization.
Also crop factors don't extend to cam shake. 250mm on crop shake as much as 250mm on ff. You need to figure stabilization for yourself. Especially on zooms. Just focus on a branch, fix iso number, and then do some tests while you decrease shutter. And mind that you won't be able to see results until you see them on big screen.

replies.text:
Hey sorry if this doesn't fit in here but I have a question kinda related.

All the photos I have inherited were shot analog. Most are darkroom prints or polaroids. I'm trying to digitize everything and I bought V600, SilverFast IT8 target, vuescan Pro. All of this still isn't getting me what I had hoped for.

I thought this all would give me the ability to put shit on the glass, hit scan, and get a nearly 1:1 digital copy. This doesn't appear to be the case.

For example if I throw a 2018 metro card in my scanner it's extremely vibrant IRL and I think it contains out of gamut colors but overall scans just doesn't seem to nail the exposure/etc here. The same goes for photos. Blacks aren't really as dark as they appear in real life and I assume this could be due to the monitor's contrast but besides that there's some slight color cast after profiling that I didn't think would be there. Editing the photos later in GIMP and applying auto levels or manual corrections helps but I thought this wouldn't be needed at all.

I have some film to scan but I was planning to work through all my paper prints before doing any film stuff. I'm aware the V600 isn't great for 35mm film but it's much better than my smartphone or camera on a light table so for under $400 total it's still a nice machine. I just expected a little more accuracy.

For example in vuescan Color Balance None scans come out weird with the it8 profile. Manual color balance fixes some of it but anything other than None seems to adjust exposure and it depends on how you crop so it's not really reliable 1:1 scanning. If a photo is faded I want it to scan that way.

Is this due to individual properties of the object/materials being scanned being different from the it8 target? Because it's reflected direct light rather than heavily diffused light? Is there no way to do easy 1:1 copying?

How can I even be confident that my IT8 target and profile are working properly? What tests can I do?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529918
>vinyl records
Thing is though that's not really true, at all, lol.

An entire analog redording and production process resulting in a vinyl record alongside digital releases can result in a potentially better vinyl but if the recordings ever existed in digital form before releasing then CD or digital format is going to sound better than vinyl 100% of the time. It's all about purity of signals and reducing the number of analog-to-digital conversions.

Photos are all originally analog. Going analog (scene) to analog (film) to digital (computer file) is worse than analog to digital directly if digital is the goal in the end. Film's only measurably superior if you're interested in future professional end drum scanning or analog prints with an enlarger avoiding digitization.

It's basically three options.
A - Analog to analog
B - Analog to digital
C - Analog to analog/digital

If you're only interested in shooting film to view your shit on a computer monitor or get scans and do digital prints you have almost no compelling reason to even consider shooting film (especially if you do color photos) and that's an objective fact.

There are some other reasons to shoot film but for the most part for people who plan around eventual digitization their choice to shoot film has got nothing to do with objective quality or properties and all to do with hipster faggot shit - or mechanical properties because film camera are GOAT and don't rely on batteries as much.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529929
That argument is stupid and lacks nuance.

First off, you have the contradiction of saying going film to digital is worse than just using a digital camera, but then saying that film is measurably better if scanned with a drum scanner.
I see your point (film and drum scanners both capture very fine details), but that doesn’t change the fact that your argument is in direct contradiction with itself.

Second, you list film to analog print as being superior.
This also is in contradiction with your argument of “the fewer number of conversions the better.”
Analog to analog processes are always lossy, this too applies to analog prints from film.
High end gear and materials minimizes these loses, but there are still losses.
Digital, on the other hand, allows for lossless conversion and editing.
Since storage space is a concern, many file types are lossy (mp3, jpeg), but professional work like studio recordings is always done with lossless formats.
Also, you’d be surprised how many audio studios use and continue to use analog tape masters.
Analog audio tapes are considered to be a better archival medium, compared to a hard drive.
That means that most vinyl records probably do have an all analog conversion chain, from master to pressing die.

>>3529938
>First off, you have the contradiction of saying going film to digital is worse than just using a digital camera, but then saying that film is measurably better if scanned with a drum scanner.
If the digital version of the photo is what's most important straight digital is the way to go.
Film is only superior when you get drum scans (which are fucking expensive btw) and even then it's just barely. Digital has gotten damn good. So good even NASA uses it.

>Second, you list film to analog print as being superior.
As opposed to Scene->Film->RGB Digital File->CMYK Digital->Analog(printer printing it)->Paper, an entirely analog process can definitely be superior. It's not a debate everyone knows this.

>Analog to analog processes are always lossy, this too applies to analog prints from film.
Still less lossy than analog->digital->analog.
Film has infinite detail. Not a meme. The captured photo info is limited, of course, but the film isn't hard capped by finite pixels like digital is. Rotations in digital require re-sampling which introduces artifacts while analog has no such issue. If you need to rotate or resize by 4 degrees and 2% it's no problem with film. Just move it physically prior to capture/print. Digital loses a slight bit of quality each time doing the same.

>Since storage space is a concern, many file types are lossy (mp3, jpeg), but professional work like studio recordings is always done with lossless formats.
Storage space actually isn't a concern.
It's super cheap these days, I don't know of any serious photographers who don't back up RAWs for important photos and they all work in high bit depth software for their editing. JPEG is for final images to simplify delivery and compatibility for easy viewing by clients/etc.

>That means that most vinyl records probably do have an all analog conversion chain, from master to pressing die.
Some simply convert digital music to vinyl just for the feels because it's a "special" format though.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529960
>Film is only superior when you get drum scans
I have a drum scanner and shooting 6x7 you can compete quite well with digital full frame. For 35mm you are probably at a level worse than micro 4/3 for most things. The difference between drums scans isn't as big as people make the sales pitch out to be. Film itself just isn't all that sharp, When I scan at 5000DPI I barely see improvements over 3000DPI, this is for a very large part due to film softness. It's nice to have a 150MP scan but upon close inspection it's pretty soft. You can also observe that if you use something like a 10x loupe on a slide.
>Digital has gotten damn good. So good even NASA uses it.
All scientific work moved to digital as soon as they could get the first CCDs. Film has never ever been able to compete.

Also I disagree on the printing narrative. You can get more resolution out of a piece of film with a nice drum scan you make a print out of than just printing the film straight. Contact prints are different but if you use an enlarger you lose resolution compared to a high quality scan you print from.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529881
I'm sure 35mm sells much better than 120. I can grab a 5 pack of Kodak Tri-X 120 for £26 new but Tri-X 35mm is about £6.50-£7.50 a roll. I think the demand for 35mm is huge at the moment but there's just enough people moving up to 120 for it stay viable.

I think eventually this fad will pass. The next generation won't remember one hour photo shops, or Kodak Gold holiday snaps, or disposable cameras. This is a very situational hipster trend of a certain breed of adult becoming nostalgic for a very particular thing. Like how Blockbuster Ex-rental tapes are exploding in value. The next generation won't remember or care.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529755
Watch out if you use 3rd party lenses from after the film era ended - I have a Tamron SP 24-70, and picked up a really nice EOS 50e a month ago, only to find out it doesn't work with that (my main) lens. This is also the case for the EOS 30, and I would presume the EOS 100 too. I have picked up an EOS 1000F N instead for next to nothing but it's nowhere near as cool as the 50e, but it works with everything, and is light and compact.

Overall, EOS cameras are all fairly good, but the downside is that none of them are particularly special. If you already have a high quality EOS lens or two, then go for it. The cameras are so cheap they're basically no-brainers at that point. The only one I'd really recommend is the 50e, but obviously not if you have recent 3rd party lenses as I specified before.

>>3529986
I don't know why people recommend the 50E. Maybe some e-celeb shilled it or it had an article on Fstoppers or something. I own one and it pales in comparison to the "professional" film bodies Canon put out at that time. The 50E has a lot of features, sure, but it feels like a hollow, plastic piece of shit. Like it feels cheaper than most modern Rebels if that's possible because there's no weighty electronics inside like we have now. I got a battery grip to see if it that would help but it still feels too hollow and light with that. If you're going to get an EOS from the film era, it's best to go for the bodies that were actually worth something.

Anything in the same class as the Canon 620/650 like the Canon EOS 5 or EOS 3 are worth it just because they don't feel like flimsy pieces of shit in your hands like the 50E does.

I used a small flashlight once and got too close. Borders looked like shit. Using a cardboard in the easel now. Put it in top left corner, expose, bottom right corner, expose. This way you get a good border.
