replies.text:
Is it worth it to develop your own (colour) film?
I looked up prices for the chemicals online, and its more expensive than I thought.

And is it reusable? I always see people in vids online pouring the shit back into the containers. But I looked it up online and people are saying not to re use them, cuz they'll fuck up your shots.

Whats the cheapest most efficient way to develop and scan your film? I'd rather do it all myself too rather than having some fag going through my shit. If its all too much of a hassle, imma just stick to digital.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3531039
Yeah, super worth it to do it yourself. A 1L kit will do 25-28ish rolls of film, so you do the math and work out how much that is per roll (hint: cheap). The chemicals are all reusable, though towards the end of their life they will need addition to time to compensate for exhausted chemicals.

In terms of scanning, if you just shoot 35mm, buy a Plustek. If you shoot 120 & 35mm, buy an Epson V550 or better

Any other questions feel free to shoot

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529929
No offense but your vinyl comparison makes literally no sense, neither does the purity of signals stuff. I literally know heaps of top engineers in my country who routinely will record to digital, then record that stuff back to tape just to get saturation and record that back to digital. Or record a digital signal back into the box to get more character from the AD converters.

Also vinyl literally is a worse format, no two ways about it. For example you can’t have any low end information in stereo, or the needle will get thrown off the track, so you have to sum everything in the low end to mono. Every album I’ve worked on that was released on vinyl has had a separate vinyl master, since you have to work against the format’s limitations and can’t use the ”true” master used for the digital release.

All that said, I don’t see vinyl dying off even if it’s technically a worse format. I mean a bunch of stuff I’ve recorded and mixed for friends were released on cassette, and that’s even worse than vinyl, yet it’s still steadily popular in certain circles. I’m sure the same applies to film, and locally I’m definitely seeing it just getting more popular. I see kids signing up to darkroom courses at community college who are young enough to have never used or seen film, even the baby photos their parents took were on digital point & shoots. People will prefer things for subjective reasons, technical details or things being objectively better simply do not matter unless you’re the most npc average consumer who only follows trends.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3531153
Even a flat bed scanner has *good enough* results for social media. You probably only upload to Instagram anyway so all the detail from a drum scan is lost by compression.

I'd go for a Plustek though if you can afford it if you shoot 35mm. Definitely better for the speed of scans alone. Or look into DSLR scanning for maximum efficiency.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3531703
Practice. I do a monthly postcard for friends and family, and this is the latest run.

The only paper I waste is when I nuke it by switching my lights on by mistake. Even then the paper is used for darkroom tools. The aim of my practice IS too ensure every print is identical during a run, and that is harder than you think. I'd like to eventually make some money from my work and for a darkroom printer consistency is critical. Every print now is a learning experience, and well worth the investment of time and materials.

And no, it's not rare plant. It's grass. I attempted to make a simple print with a strong visual impact.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: Just ordered a 30m bulk roll of the new Agfa Apx 400, was almost going to go with Foma again but decided to try out the Agfa, since I read online it’s by Harman and actually the same stock as Kentmere 400 and Rollei Rpx 400. I liked both of those stocks a lot, so will be interesting to see if it’s true. Anyone here shoot it yet? The price is really nice with bulk Hp5 now over €80 already, though I think I’ll still use Hp5 for anything important.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3531882
Fill us in once you've shot a roll or two. I'm also in need of 30,5m of something, probably gonna be RPX 400 again at this rate, maybe two reels since its price has been going up. But I'm also looking at 30,5m of Kentmere 400 since hey, apparently that's available in bulk now too.

I don't believe a word of any rumour saying that there's a 1:1 correspondence between Agfa APX 400, Kentmere 400, and Rollei RPX 400. To my understanding the modern APX 400 is a contemporary recipe created after Agfa went tits-up and its bits were scattered to the winds. Rollei RPX 400 is what became of the "old" APX 400 recipe, and supposedly it's made in Germany -- but what degree of "made" this is, is up to question. Kentmere 400 is what used to be Kentmere 400 before Kentmere-the-company went similarly tits-up and was bought out by Ilford, persisting as their non-primary brand in Europe.

In any case I've found Kentmere 400 and RPX 400, both in HC-110(B), to have quite distinct density response curves. Kentmere being more opinionated on contrast, and RPX 400 being linear and easy in the darkroom. Similarly Kentmere 400 doesn't push to 1600 easily in HC-110 where RPX 400 at EI1600 is just the cat's pajamas.

>>476997608
let me give you a tip
you might be interested in reading all 50+ books of the horus heresy
you might find people telling you that only 10 or so are worth reading
you might shrug it off and assume its bullshit and that you'll read them all
you might find the stray good book I.E all of the books involving nathaniel garro or the alpha legion restoring your faith in the emperor
but you will find that most of the books are the fucking same
there's only so many ways you can describe what happens to soft, exposed tissue when a bolter round hits it, or how many ways a suit of ceramite can crack or chip when exposed to high force
and the books are pretty much this, except there's a few really cool parts that deviate from the norm
20+ books in and you reach books about the blood angels or the raven guard, even the iron warriors, and they end up sounding pretty much identical with similar plots
but then you get books describing fulgrim enjoying having a pear of agony crammed up his ass, and then removing it WHILE ITS OPEN and wishing he hadn't because it was so nice
so uh, pinch of salt
i definitely recommend skipping like 75% of the horus heresy and just hitting up the good shit, though

>>476957270
You mean how the first Metal Gear games were on the NES, and how The Twin Snakes was a landmark Gamecube game?
Or do you mean how Sonic has had a home on Nintendo consoles since the year 2000?
Maybe you're referring to how Mega Man was born and raised on the NES.
Or you could mean Pac-Man, who has had Nintendo games all the way from the NES to the current year.
You could mean Ryu and Ken, who finally brought Street Fighter to home consoles on the SNES.
We can't forget Cloud of course. He may be from a PSX game, but he is the face of Final Fantasy, which had it's origins on Nintendo systems. A gesture of good will from Square Enix.
You can't possibly mean Bayonetta, seeing as her games are exclusive to Nintendo consoles now. Even you can't be that retarded.
I wouldn't put it past you being retarded enough to forget the Belmonts though. The best games in their series are on NES and SNES.
Not thinking of Joker, are you? He's the current face of the Shin Megami Tensei series, which had its beginning on, you guessed it, the Famicom.
I shouldn't even have to explain the Dragon Quest hero, and if I do you're even more dense than I imagined.
Banjo's only notable games were on the Nintendo 64.
And finally, Terry Bogard has been kicking it on Nintendo consoles since the first Fatal Fury game in 1992.
In conclusion, eat shit and die.

The best thing I can say about Astral Chain is that it understands moderation very well (File 8 notwithstanding).
Sure, any of the side activity types would be annoying if I had to do them 100 times in a row for 100% completion, but there's so few of them and they're mixed up enough in terms of frequency that I never get irritated. replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>476967269
I'm going to try to break it down into chunks for you.

The story is basically Eva but Evas are stands on a leash. The game is very heavily built around story "moments" and there's a lot of downtime and cutscenes. 99% of the game's mechanics are locked in the first two chapters, then it dumps half of them on you at once, then the rest is either locked behind story moments or buried deep in skill trees

The gameplay is split into three sections: base, cop work, and combat.

At the base you customize and upgrade your character.
In cop work you go around a small city level talking to everyone and doing fetch quests and barebones Phoenix Wright stuff (hint: the answer is always "it's a chimera)

The combat is difficult to explain because it's so different from anything else and comparisons to Bayonetta or W101 are terrible and will probably make you dislike the game. Legions will auto-attack and have to skills you set yourself You hit L2 to summon your legion, hold L2 and move the right stick to move it and use X and Y while holding it to use their skills, tap L2 with it out to send it after an enemy, hold L2 and hit R2 to jump to it, and use L2 when there's a flash to do a sync attack with it. R2 is attack for your character and R1 returns the legion to recharge. L1 is a unique skill for each legion.

It's kinda shakey to be honest. Moving legions with the right stick locks the camera, and the camera by itself is already bad. Rankings are based solely on how many different techniques you used in one fight. Most fights have some kind of extra obstacle like sticky floors or holes. It's bold and experimental, but as a result also awkward and under-developed

replies.text:
Case 3: There's a heavy chest plate in the Astral plain in a side area after going up with the first raising platform

Case 3: hidden holo-mask salesman behind a holographic wall in the alley you start in. Skull and Hermit holo-masks.

Case 4: After acquiring the Arm legion, move back to the staircase and chain jump across to a gate that can be lifted. Goggles.

Secret Hologram wall near the burger store selling vendor-3 and hermit mask

Case 5: At the Aegis Institute you can find an eyepatch in one of the medical rooms.(sorry, forgot the exact one.)

Case 6: A cardboard box hat is under a staircase in the area you are tracking Douglas with the Beast Legion.

Case 7: After dealing with the horde of flying chimera's, in the left area Square Glasses B will be under the stairs

in the area where you rescue Alan from falling, the Cat Holo-Mask is on the pipeline

headset down the tunnel where the homunculus attacks (the area where you gotta walk the officer to be airlifted out)

the civilian mask is found in the blue case to hunt down the elemental, same area as the airlifted man, inspect the red gash in the groundto start it and find ot in the astral plane it leads you to

Case 8: help Billy (the guy with the sunglasses) take down a terrorist plot and earn a pair of sunglasses of your own.

Case 11: When you reach the Roof of the ARI, dont wall into Akira, instead walk around her and go up the stairs. on the right side you will find the Lappy Holo Mask

>>476968381
The number of enemies in the game is a little misleading though because most of them are based around the same handful of archetypes. The main thing that sets AC apart in that and makes it feel less repetitive and tedious is that it is near constantly introducing new variants of those archetypes and several of them come with unique attacks specific to that variant. The only major exception is the gel chimeras which all feel exactly the same to fight.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>476969519
dodging isn't difficult, you just need to untrain yourself from using it like most stylish action games. You can't cancel attacks with it and one perfect dodge often isn't enough to allow retaliation. Don't overcommit to combo strings or you won't be able to dodge when the enemy starts their attack. Likewise, make sure an enemy has finished their whole attack string before you initiate a sync attack or start hitting back. If an enemy attack has 3 swings, don't start attacking after dodging the first because it generally will not interrupt it. Dodge all three swings and THEN counter.

>>476969853
>>476970632
Max is the Axe Legion now. Unless they make it a plot point to separate him from his Legion, he's not coming back. I honestly doubt they would do that because it would completely undermine the impact of his loss on the characters and render his sacrifice and his reveal as the Axe Legion, still protecting his child, completely toothless. The writers seem to want to make plot points like that mean something so I doubt they would just go and undo it.

Hell, even Akira coming back at the end wasn't a complete "happy ending" cop-out because it's not even the original Akira. It was one of the clones that they just found in the aftermath and implanted with as many of Akira's old memories as they could from his/her Legion. It's Akira but at the same time, it's still an imitation and the characters all have to live with that knowledge, knowing the real one sacrificed themselves to stop Noah. It seems implied that it's a secret too and if anything, a likely plot point of the sequel will be Akira finding out he/she is a clone and having to wrestle with that existential crisis, revisiting the borderline throwaway crisis of Akira wondering if he/she was the original or not near the very end.

>TV series, second OVA

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>476950385
Yeah it's the unity port. It's just such a fun game to play. But be aware if you think Daggerfall is anything like other elder scrolls you are in for a surprise. It is much more like Diablo 1 then anything because the whole game revolves around dungeon diving. Seriously like 95% of the quests involve dungeon crawling. It does it well though. It's so much fun because you can climb, hang from ceilings and pretty much parkour through dungeons. I recommend turning the smaller dungeons option on in the ini file because every single dungeon would take hours of your time. Though this doesn't effect main quest or quest mod dungeons.
Always create a custom class as well because the premade ones are crap. It's so much fun using the class maker anyway you won't mind it.

As for the depression I appreciate your sentiments, but I been depressed well over 10 years now. Life just seems to get worse and worse gradually. I have no friends, and I cannot make friends for the life of me. I'm 28 friendless, a virgin, and I work at a fast food joint. I also have heart problems on top of that so it makes basic stuff hard for me to do. God I need a drink now.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
DMC3 and DMC1 are more memorable games than DMC5.

It's a shame because that statement is a real mixed bag. I'm a firm proponent that the "puzzles" and backtracking drive engagement with the level and world. Both DMC1 and 3 have you traverse a single area for most of the game and you get to know its layout pretty well and see how it changes over time. It is neat when you see an area you know changed slightly (or not-so-slightly) later in the game due to things that you've been doing. The puzzles break up the pacing in the game. Things can feel varied and segments of the game get to feel like their own distinct segments when you think back on them later. Unfortunately, a lot of the "puzzles" in DMC games are dogshit. There are a few that are good (infinite DT with draining health in DMC3) and some that I personally think work well (chess board in DMC3) because they involve combat mechanics in new ways, but the games definitely miss more than they hit.

And it's a shame because DMC5 is the best the game's combat has ever been. Some people may gripe about a few unintended mechanics from 4 being missing, but on the whole, it's the best it's ever been. However, the levels are nothing but fight rooms connected by corridors. There's one "puzzle" in the whole game and Dante spends half that time quipping about how it's a "puzzle." What's worse is that the different fight locales rarely use setpieces of any kind. There are some bits where Goliath throws cars at you and some floors that fall out if too many enemies pile up and the opera house, but those are the only things I can think of. Every other fight is just being locked in a room with a bunch of bad guys until you beat them all to death. Then you move onto the next one. In higher difficulties, where enemy placement gets shuffled around, I honestly can't separate most of the levels or fights from each other in my head, aside from a few standout things like 3 speed lizards at the same time.

You're right. As soon as I posted, I realized I forgot to talk about the ONE good area in the game with regards to pacing. The one where you can find a bunch of diverging routes based on the Devil Breakers you have is probably one of my favorite levels. replies.text:
>>476984164
>>476984164
An actual villain while the Vergil split acts as a subplot that ties into the main one.
Less poor attempts at fan service that are only on superficial level.
Cinematography and camera shots like in old games.
More crazy cutscenes and impressive feats.
Trying to tell stories of 3 characters on a game that didn't have a big budget.
Dante not being a washed up hobo.
A story with actual stakes till the end. Only the prologue has semblance of this.
They shouldn't have had the Eva cutscene.
Dante conveniently stumbling on his old house.
Dante not loosing both Rebellion and Sparda just to get an ugly sword.
Shouldn't have retconned Vergil into being jealous of Dante.
Vergil not becoming a good guy.
More exchanges with the bosses.
Lady and Trish could've had more screen time and story importance.
Nico could've had less screen time.
Not blatantly taking things from DmC like cheap slowmos and camera zoom ins
Not presenting important plot points in the middle of battles that can be cut off.
OST was a mixed bag. They experimented too much with modern electro music.
No one asked for realistic graphics.
Someone actually crying.
Costumes
Like others said, V wasn't necessary or at least didn't have to be playable.
Enemies that are an actual threat.
Shouldn't have patched reversals. It wasn't harmful to anyone.
Not botching the lock-on targeting priority.
I'm sure I could write plenty more, but that's enough

replies.text:
How are you supposed to get into fighting games? They dont really have any sort of tutorial or easing in. You just start. Especially with arcades and it cost money to play. How were people expected to learn and stay interested?

Let's say you're 12 and live in mexico and you have a handful of pesos and there's a weird video game machine at the corner store and it has a game called king of fighters 97. You pop in a couple of pesos and you try to play and you have ZERO clue as to what you're doing or how you're supposed to execute those fancy moves the ai is doing. You lose right away. Would you continue blowing what little cash you have or move on? What in what you just did would compel you to continue?

I played them but I never quite understood how you were supposed to learn the game without cutting your losses and doing something more immediately rewarding
